title: 100mph winds approaching Japan as Typhoon Hagibis closes in
text:
Typhoon Hagibis, said to be the worst storm to hit Japan in 60 years is set to hit today (Pictures: EPA)

A person has died as Japan’s worst super storm in 60 years begins to batter the country.

Typhoon Hagibis is set to strike within the next few hours with pre-storm downpours and strong winds already bringing flooding and widespread disruption.

Across the Tokyo Bay in Chiba, a tornado overturned a car killing a man inside, city official Tatsuya Sakamaki said.

Five people were also injured when the tornado tore through a house on Saturday, though their injuries were said to be non life-threatening.

The army has been put on standby with an estimated 17,000 police and military troops called up, ready for rescue operations the government said.

Chiba is still recovering after being hit by a typhoon last month, suffering power outages and flooding and its people are bracing themselves for worse to come.

Satellite image showing Typhoon Hagibis spinning over the western Pacific Ocean as its outer cloud bands near Japan (Picture: NASA EARTH OBSERVATORY)

A sign outside of the Yokohama Stadium showing England v France has been cancelled (Photo: Forster/Getty Images)

As Typhoon Hagibis approaches Yokohama supermarkets and convenience stores begin to run out of essentials such as bread as people stockpile food (Picture: Icon Sport)

Men look at fishing boats as surging waves hit against the breakwater while Typhoon Hagibis approaches at a port in town of Kiho (Picture: AP)

Hagibis is expected to be the biggest storm to hit the region since 1958 when more than 1,200 people were killed and half-million houses flooded, prompting drastic measures as people strip stores to stockpile food and water.

Pre-storm rains have already caused rivers to swell, flipped anchored boats and whipped surging sea waters along the coast causing flooding and leaving people wading in ankle-deep waters. Authorities also warned of mudslides, common in mountainous Japan.

Dozens of evacuation centres have opened in coastal towns, and people have begun to move in, resting on gymnasium floors.

Organisers of rugby union’s world cup have cancelled this weekends fixtures, including England vs France.

Japan’s organising body tweeted a pictured of the team’s players piggybacking on each other to get from their changing rooms to the field.

Flights and train services have been halted along Japan’s Pacific coast region and in Kiho, southwest of Tokyo. The government has already warned people to avoid high-risk places.

Meteorological Agency forecast department chief Yasushi Kajihara said: ‘In order to protect your own life and your loved ones, please try to start evacuating early before it gets dark and the storm becomes powerful.’

Qualifying for Formula One’ Suzuka race was pushed to Sunday. The Defence Ministry cut a three-day annual navy review to a single day on Monday.

Mike Alsop, 57-year-old executive coach from England, was visiting Japan for the World Rugby tournament, but was left stranded at an abandoned Tokyo train station.

‘We were hoping to watch England play against France today, disappointed that we won’t be able to but completely understand it,’ he said.
